firstAttestation.description: Estimated based on mythology literary tradition

longDescription: The laurel or bay tree (Greek: Œ¥Œ¨œÜŒΩŒ∑ daphne) is sacred to Apollo, god of prophecy, music, and the arts. According to myth, the nymph Daphne transformed into a laurel tree to escape Apollo's pursuit, and Apollo declared the tree sacred to him thereafter. Laurel wreaths crowned victors in the Pythian Games at Delphi, poets and artists, and military commanders celebrating triumphs. The Pythia (Oracle of Delphi) chewed laurel leaves to induce prophetic trances, and laurel branches purified sacred spaces. The tree's evergreen nature symbolized immortality and eternal glory, while its aromatic properties connected it to divine inspiration and purification. Apollo's lyre was often made with laurel wood, linking the tree to artistic creativity.
name: Laurel
shortDescription: Sacred bay tree of Apollo, symbol of victory, prophecy, poetic inspiration, and purification

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The laurel symbolizes Apollo's domains: prophecy (oracular use), poetry and music (crowning bards), victory (Pythian Games), and purification (cleansing rites). Its evergreen nature represents eternal glory and immortal fame‚Äîkleos aphthiton (imperishable glory) sought by Greek heroes. The Daphne myth adds layers of meaning: unrequited love, transformation, the boundary between divine and mortal realms, and how loss can be transmuted into sacred beauty. The aromatic leaves suggest divine inspiration‚Äîpoets and prophets alike breathe the laurel's essence to access higher knowledge.
mythologyContexts.usage: Sacred to Apollo as symbol of prophecy, victory, and artistic inspiration; laurel wreaths crowned victors and poets; laurel leaves used in oracular divination and purification

rituals.name: Pythian Games

rituals.description: The Pythia chewed laurel leaves to induce prophetic trance states
rituals.name: Delphic Oracle
Purification Rites
rituals.description: Laurel branches sprinkled with water to purify sacred spaces

mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Laurel wreaths (corona triumphalis in Latin) became the ultimate symbol of victory and excellence in Greco-Roman culture. 'Laureate' derives from laurel (poet laureate, Nobel laureate). 'Resting on one's laurels' and 'winning one's laurels' entered common speech. The bay leaf remains a culinary staple, connecting ancient sacred use to everyday life. Modern academic regalia and victory ceremonies echo ancient laurel crowning. The laurel symbolizes the immortality conferred by great achievement in arts, athletics, or war.
